109922.name: Combat Infantry
109922.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Combat Infantry, previously known as K.I.S.S. and Courage, is a fast-paced World War II tactical level game that employs wooden blocks. The game system features innovative and interactive rules for Fire Combat, Close Combat, Morale, and Leaders. The game delivers a high level of tactical realism, yet is very playable.

In the game, you command a German or American infantry battalion, composed of three infantry companies and a heavy weapons company. Future expansion sets will include British, Soviet, Italian, and Japanese battalions. Unit types include:


Leaders
Rifle Squads
Machine Guns
Mortars
Anti-Tank
Tank


The game is not card driven; units are activated by company and platoon leaders. The game includes four geomorphic maps at a scale of 100 meters per hex. Extra maps will be available for separate purchase.

109923.name: Robot Sam the Answer Man
109923.description: Electric quiz game with extraordinary graphics. Answer questions and point to the correct answer, and a bulb will light up. The game contains 6 answer sheets but double-sided to give you more replayability.

109924.name: Cro-Magnon Rrrevolution
109924.description:
The pre-hysteria with stones.

After their first game on the subject called "Cro-Magnon" the team behind that game comes up with the follow-up called "Cro-Magnon Rrrévolution", which is a completely independent game from the original.

As in the original, you play as a tribe that will evolve over time. The change is that this time every time you move your pawn on the track and change area, the playing conditions change. As in the first version, the basic principle is to make your tribe guess as many words as they can.

The method of making the tribe guess the words is what changes each time. In the first age it's miming combined with an uncontrollable effect of a die; in the second age, you will make shapes with stones; later you can talk only with words that never contain the letter of your tribe taboo; and finally in the fourth age you can use overlapping cardboard shapes to evoke the mystery word...

"Cro-Magnon Rrrévolution" is a game of communication and pure atmosphere.

109925.name: Splash Page Special
109925.description:
The title appears to be an old journalism phrase, relating to special editions with lots of photographs about a special event.
Players must collect sets of two or three, by enquiring of other players "Do you have card so-and-so?". If a player gets a pair, he may play it in front of him but should someone get the third, they can claim the other two. At the end, a set in front of you scores points (each set varies in this regard). First to 50 points, wins.
The Splash Page Special card is a kind of Joker and is the only card not relating to a unique set.
Variant rules are provided for playing a type of Snap with the same cards.

109926.name: Fortune Cookies and Nuclear War (Booklet Edition)
109926.description:
User Summary:
The booklet is nearly the same as the "Nano" card edition, but it includes sheets for recording demands, secret goals, and concessions.

109927.name: Over The Rooftops
109927.description:
Publisher blurb:

Jonathan Roberts, cartographer for Kobold Quarterly, The Breaking of Forstor Nagar, and Adventures in the Hyborian Age, presents another Fantastic Map: "Over The Rooftops."

This multi-page PDF allows you to print out the battlemap at a 1 square=1 inch scale as a letter-format or A4 map and is also available in a printer-friendly light grayscale version. High-Resolution JPEGs of the maps with and without grids, along with individual images for the barricades, ladders, lightning ballista, target areas, and wagons. The file also contains a MapTool file set up for quick use in a 4E, PFRPG, or any OGL game. The MapTool file requires MapTool 1.3b86 or newer to work.

Created as part of The Breaking of Forstor Nagar (Pathfinder RPG).

109928.name: Torope: Hard-Shell Hero
109928.description:
From publisher blurb:

Do you love anthropomorphic turtles? Come on... you can't say 'no' to that question. It's time to enjoy a 4e/gsl race of bipedal turtle who gains an AC bonus from its shell, who can store their nunchaku on their back, and who travels the world as a stalwart adventurer. The torope is a fully playable PC race from Escape Velocity Gaming being distributed for free to our fans as a thank you for their support! Plus, how many racial guides come with a recipe?

109929.name: Smurfs Hold On Clumsy
109929.description: Don't let Clumsy fall! Clumsy Smurfs sits on top of a wall of bricks. Take turns using Gargamel’s wand to push out the bricks one at time, but it's only a matter of time before Clumsy tumbles down. Don’t let it be YOU!

109931.name: Eyeshield 21: Max Devil Power
109931.description:
User Summary

Football game based on the anime and manga franchise Eyeshield 21. Released only in Japan. Includes a story mode and single game mode.

109932.description:
Miskatonic School for Girls is the first deck-building game in which you get to build your opponent's deck. This unique feature creates a totally different play dynamic from other deck building games.

MSFG has players assuming the roles of rival houses at Miskatonic. Each house has a healthy level of sanity (20) at the beginning of the game. As the game goes on, that precious sanity will slowly be torn away by the faculty of the school. In order to combat the bad teaching methods of the Great Old Ones, the students of the house need to band together!

During your turn, you'll buy your new friends with friendship points and use nightmare points to send faculty after the rival houses. Eventually, those Faculty will end up in a player's hand, where they will hold class, teaching your innocent students about the horrors around them. This has a detrimental effect on your house's sanity.

Due to the overwhelming power of the dark truth, it's just a matter of time before your house goes completely bonkers. The last house left with any sanity wins!
109932.name: Miskatonic School for Girls
boardgameexpansion: Miskatonic School for Girls: Holiday Break
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 2 The Geekcast That Didn’t Want To Be
OBG 84: The Dewey Game Collection Lifecycle

109933.name: Ugly Americans: Apocalypsegeddon
109933.description:
Hearkening back to such classics as Gauntlet and Robotron, "Ugly Americans: Apocalypsegeddon" features four playable characters, each with their own unique abilities, weapons and strengths. Players must comb the streets of New York City and pacify raving demons, delinquent man birds and zombies by lactating fire and hurling any item at their disposal such as demon skulls, fish, baseballs and wrenches. Investigate case files from the Department of Integration and battle devastating and distinctive bosses at the end of each mission, each bringing you one step closer to finding out who is trying to bring about the end of days!

Source: The Publisher Website.

109934.name: Crimson Alliance
109934.description:
Crimson Alliance is a co-op action role-playing game developed by Certain Affinity and published by Microsoft Studios. The game was first announced in May 2011 at a Rooster Teeth event and was available for demo at E3, ComicCon and PAX Prime, with the press release being announced on May 31, 2011.
Crimson Alliance was released on September 7, 2011 on Xbox LIVE Arcade for free as a freemium. Player can choose to pay between 800 Microsoft Points for one character class or 1200 Microsoft Points for all three character classes. The game was also offered as a free bonus code download for those who purchased all five of the fourth annual Xbox Live Summer of Arcade titles before August 23, 2011.

Source: Wikipedia, "Crimson Alliance", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

109935.description:
Roar like a lion, waddle like a duck, draw an elephant on the table, explain what a dolphin eats, and tell where a bear lives: In Kikerikimäh!?, for two players or 3-6 players, whoever can do that the best, leading the other players more often than not in the right direction, will win the game.

To set up the game for 3-6 players, shuffle the 56 animal cards, then deal out cards as evenly as possible among all the players. If a player receives a matching pair of animal cards, remove these from the game as they are not needed. Shuffle the challenge cards and place them in the middle of the table.

On a turn, the active player draws the topmost challenge card – with challenges being something that you draw or describe or imitate, e.g., "describe the animal's feet", "using your fingers, mimic how the animal walks" or "describe or show how the animal eats". This player draws the topmost animal card from her deck, then completes the challenge as best she can. Each other player then looks through their personal deck of animal cards, chooses one animal they think best matches the description or sounds given, then reveal these cards simultaneously. If someone has matched the active player, those two cards are removed from play; likewise, if any two players have revealed matching animals, those cards are removed from play. All other animals are returned to their owners' decks. The next player then undergoes a challenge, and so on.

As soon as one or more players have no animal cards remaining, the game ends and those players win.

In the two-player game, each player takes a set of animal cards and they take turns doing the challenges. If the non-active player reveals the right animal card, those cards are removed from play; otherwise, the challenger's card and the matching card from the other player's deck are placed in the middle of the table as a penalty point. The goal is to score as few penalty points as possible.
109935.name: Kikerikimäh!?

109936.name: Fliegende Teppiche
109936.description:
With the sun setting in the horizon, adventurers glide in on their flying carpets, searching for valuable treasures in palaces and bazaars. But steering a flying carpet to the proper destination is a lot trickier than it sounds. A strong wind can push a carpet off its course and into a desert, even though its intended destination was the camel bazaar. But maybe the magic lamp can still save the day?

In Fliegende Teppiche ("Flying Carpets"), players try to guide their flying carpets to the most attractive destinations to score the most points – and by "guide" read "toss" as the carpets are actually cards. To set up the game, each player receives one carpet (two in a two-player game) and a set of genie cards. Shuffle the 52 destination cards.

To set up a round, the active player turns over destination cards one by one and places them on the table as she desires. A card can't be placed more than the width of a card away from other cards, and at least 1 cm must separate adjacent cards. After revealing twelve cards, the player can swap cards or rearrange them to some degree. Then the player to her left "flies" his carpet onto the destination cards, followed by each other player with the active player going last. Once all carpets have flown, check to see who claims what:


If a carpet lies on no destination cards (or is only underneath cards), return it to its owner, who receives nothing.
If a carpet is alone on top of one or more destination cards, the carpet's owner claims these cards, whether or not he wants to.
If more than one carpet is on a destination card, the players involved simultaneously reveal one of their genie cards. The player with the highest genie claims the destination card, then swaps that genie with the player who revealed the lowest genie.


If four or more destination cards are still on the table (and they're not all deserts), fly the carpets again. Once fewer than four cards remain, compare the number of palaces held by each player (with magic lamps counting as a palace if a player chooses to do this). The player(s) with the most palaces scores five points, while the player(s) with the fewest loses five points. Remove palace and used lamp cards from play, then pass the destination deck to the next player, who lays out twelve more cards. Players toss carpets, etc.

Once all players have laid out cards once (twice in a two-player game), the game ends. Players score additional points for claiming pairs of matching bazaars (5-7 points), sets of different adventure cards (1-15 points), and treasures (3 points), while losing five points for each desert claimed. Magic lamps can cancel a desert or be used as a wild card. The player with the most points wins.

109937.description:
In Marienkäfer und so, ladybugs and other insects are crawling all over the cards. Try to find them based on their silhouetted profiles before the other players do – but that's not easy as the insect marked through on your search card must not be anywhere on the insect card!

The 63 insect cards feature three colored insects (all different) on one side of the card and three silhouetted insects on the reverse side, with one of those insects having a large X through it. Shuffle the deck with the black-and-white images face up, then deal one card to each player; this card is a player's search card.

On a turn, the player who last claimed a card (chosen randomly in the first round) flips over the top card of the deck. Each player races to slap this card – but only if the newly revealed card depicts at least one of the two non-Xed insects on that player's search card and that player's Xed insect is not on the newly revealed card. If the first player to slap the card has done so correctly, he claims the card, placing it black-and-white side up on his stack to become his new search card; if the first player has slapped the card incorrectly (as his Xed insect is on the card or neither of his other two search targets are present), that player must remove the bottom card of his search stack from the game. The slapped card is also removed from play. (A player can't lose his only search card. If no one slaps the card, remove it from play, then reveal the next card.)

Play continues until the final insect card has been slapped. Whoever has the most cards in his search deck wins.

For children as young as age three, Marienkäfer und so can be played with players taking turns consecutively instead of playing simultaneously. If a player can claim a card, he does so, making it his new search card; otherwise he removes it from play.

A second game is included in Marienkäfer und so. Shuffle the insect cards black-and-white side face up, then deal seven cards to each player. All players simultaneously flip their top card color-side up onto the table, then race to slap an insect card in front of another player that matches the search criteria on the newly revealed top card of their personal deck. Each card can be claimed by only one player, i.e., whoever slaps it first. If a player slaps a card correctly, he places it on the bottom of his deck black-and-white side face up; if a player slaps a card incorrectly, his current search card is removed from play. All unslapped cards are also removed from play. The game ends when one or more players have only a single card in their deck; the player(s) with the most cards in their deck(s) wins.
109937.name: Marienkäfer und so

109938.name: Plushed Gold Fever
109938.description:
The Voodoo Mouse has scattered all the Plush Toys over the Wild West. A lone horse rides to the rescue, searching from mine shaft to mine shaft to free them all from the Voodoo Mouse's curse. Join him in his quest to make things right, while satisfying your craving for gold, in Plushed Gold Fever.

Source: The Developer Website.

109939.name: Wiggle Waggle
109939.description:
Game No 4375. For two or more players.

Directions for Playing : Place a ball upon each of the pedestals in the bottom of the box, placing them on the pedestal or corresponding color. To Wind the top: Place the wooden disk over the center pin with the small metal pin and end of wire spring against the top of the top. Hold the bottom part of the top firmly in the left hand and give the wooden disk a few turns to the right. To release the spinning part of the top, hold the wooden disk firmly in the hand and press one finger on the center of the metal pin. The spinning top must be dropped into the center small circle of the playing board. Each player has one spin at a turn and at the end of his turn the score is taken, counting the numbers in front of the pedestals from which a ball has been thrown. If two balls of one color are thrown, it doubles the score of those two balls. A game may consist of 300 points; or it may be played by rounds, the player having the greatest score at the end of an agreed upon number of rounds, being the winner."

The pedestals are numbered as follows in clockwise direction :

Red: 20 points
Blue: 15 points
Green: 10 points
Yellow: 5 points
Orange: 10 points
Red: 5 points
Blue: 20 points
Green: 15 points
Yellow: 10 points
Orange: 5 points

There is a wooden coloured ball, corresponding in number and colour to each pedestal. The game is played inside a square wooden box with a height of about 5cm (2"). The box is 34cm square (13.5").

Rules for this game come from --- Famous Belgian (famousbelgian). He also contributed a couple of pictures of the game which was in the Unidentified Game geeklist.

109940.name: Aurum Blade
109940.description:
The essence of ancient Alchemy, the Philosopher's Stone, has been hidden in the Philosopher's Tower until now, and for good reason. But now Duke Marduk is heading to the tower to take the stone and use it. But for what? And why has he abducted Celty, the mysterious girl from Shining Dawn Village, who is somehow connected to it all? One thing is clear, terrible things are happening, and Duke Marduk must be stopped. Someone must be a hero in this world!

Aurum Blade is a fast-paced action RPG with thrilling attack weapons and spells, and truly enjoyable control. All of this and more is waiting to be discovered.

Source: The Developer Website.

109942.name: Disney's Dinosaur
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Color edition
109942.description:
Disney's Dinosaur is a 2000 video game released as a tie-in to the Disney film of the same name. The game loosely follows the story of the film, starting with Aladar, Zini and Flia on the Lemur Island. The island is destroyed in a meteor shower, forcing Aladar and his friends to flee to the mainland, where they encounter a herd of dinosaurs led by the ruthless Kron.

Most of the game consists of solving puzzles and fighting off predators. To accomplish these goals, the player has the ability to switch between Aladar, Zini and Flia, or use them in conjunction.

Source: Wikipedia, "Disney's Dinosaur (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

109943.name: A Knights Dawn
109943.description:
"Sometimes a finger is mightier than the sword"

Use the intuitive one-finger- Controls to command your army, browse the Levels and upgrade your units.

In "a Knights Dawn" you don’t just build towers like in traditional tower defense games - simply massing towers. Here you must place your units strategically, for example taking the terrain into account and placing the weaker musketeers or mages in locations protected by the stronger defensive forces.

But Beware - the enemy is tricky and vicious at the same time. You will fight battles to defend your airship, hold the horde back long enough in order to give your people time to flee and prevent the enemies from the revival of a monstrous sea creature.

After a battle you will have the chance to further upgrade your troops, and prepare them for more intense fights to come. However your troops aren´t the only thing that upgrades.

As your troops get stronger during the story they will need a fortified place to live and rest between the exhausting fights.

So, throughout the game city and land around you will evolve, starting with a simple camp without any protection. You will be able to turn it into a powerful fortress, and maybe even into the Main City State of your country. If you survive long enough.

Oh and one more thing, your camp isn´t just eye candy, it´s actually the games main menu, here you´ll be able to upgrade your units, change your profile, check out your accomplishments or head right back into the heat of battle.

We also make sure you have plenty to do after getting through the story, with tons of achievements, challenges and difficulties to get through. Oh and don’t forget to post your accomplishments to Facebook via Facebook integration, go ahead and show your friends who the real king is.

Source: The Developer Website.

109945.name: Бронепехота
109945.description: Бронепехота (armor infantry) is a sci-fi tabletop game with miniatures. Each player is the head of the military forces of one of the opposing star powers. The rules aren't extensive, but wide enough to cover many nuances of intense fighting in the Star Era. There are two ways of shooting: real and virtual. Some weapons actually launch plastic missiles. Virtual firing is resolved using dice rolls. The rules contain corresponding chapters if players wish to switch from one firing way to another. Warriors, cannons and fighting machines are snap together kits requiring no glue for assembly.

109946.name: Guide to Elite Nazi Units (Ubiquity)
109946.description:
From the publisher:

A staple of the pulp genre, Nazis are foes characters love to hate. This Ubiquity supplement details three unusual Nazi units: SS-Sturmbataillon Fenrir, an all-female SS unit better known as the Valkyries; the high-flying Zeppelintruppen, protectors of Hitler's airship fleet; and the collection of psychotics that form Stahl-Mask’s Doom Squad.

Each unit has its history, uniform, purpose, and favored weapons described, along with complete stats to allow you to drop these bad boys and girls straight into your high-octane pulp game.

109948.name: Звездный рубеж
109948.description:
A rare mineral was found on the planet Arktal-3. Needed by all advanced civilizations in the galaxy.
Grab the field, build factories, research centers and increase the power of your army, to achieve victory and secure your civilization the most important resources.

Звездный рубеж (Star Frontier) is a light miniature war game played on modular hextiles.
The units are composed of infantry, mechas and various tanks, produced in factories.
Players can use research cards to increase the power of their units.

The game comes with:
9 Hextiles.
20 Cyper Marines
14 Tanks (light, heavy, missile launchers)
4 Mechas
56 Construction pieces
64 Resource tokens
A 12 sided die
1 Rulebook
24 Research cards

109949.name: In Search of the Unknown:  Campaign Sourcebook
rpgcategory: Non-Rankable Item (item will not show in the rankings)
109949.description:
subtitle:
a collection of original work and material
gathered from the pages of Dragonsfoot and
elsewhere on the internet

User summary:
This collection of essays, analyses, advice and examples of completed dungeons (B1 is intentionally incomplete) is available from the Zenopus Archives.

Table of Contents;
Retrospective: In Search of the Unknown by James Maliszewski

Q&A with Mike Carr by Geoffrey McKinney

Memories of David C. Sutherland III by Robert J. Kuntz

Interview: Darlene by James Maliszewski

Review: Holmes Basic by Bill Silvey

Printing History with notes from the Acaeum

Unknown Designs by Demos Sachlas

Architecture of Quasqueton by Gabor Lux

Prosopographies: by Demos Sachlas

Quasqueton in the World of Greyhawk by Demos Sachlas

The Continental Map: D&D Game Campaign Setting by Demos Sachlas

Sample Stocking II: Using Subsequent Editions by C. Wesley Clough

Module B1: Updated for a Mystara Campaign by Jenni A.M. Merrifield

Sample Stocking III: Using Redrawn Map by Daniel H. Boggs

Redesign of Upper Level by Mike and Arzon the Mighty

Quasqueton Tower By Shadow Shack

Remembering Quasqueton from the Dragonsfoot Forums

Acknowledgements

109950.name: Record of the Three Kingdoms
109950.description: Background of the game is set during the Three Kingdoms period. Each player will take the role of one of the lords. Each lord has an unique ability which if well utilised may be one of the factor impacting a player’s route to victory. In addition, players will get to come across well know generals from the Three Kingdoms era. With a unique battle system, military force will not be the only key deciding factor to winning. Clever use of tactic may change the situation of the war, making it possible for a weaker general to beat a better known general. To unify the world and win the game, having a good strategist is definitely indispensable.

109955.name: The Eye of All-Seeing Wonder (Issue 1 - Autumn 1992)
rpgissuearticle: The Clan of the Iron Plume
The Relative Status of the Legions
109955.description:
table of contents:
Contents

Opening the Way
Editorial from Dave Morris.

Welcome to Jakálla
Michael Cule presents the story of the Hill People’s arrival in Tsolyánu. An introductory scenario for GURPS Tékumel.

The Epic of Hrugga
The deeds of the favourite Tsolyáni folk-hero, as recounted by David Bailey. Find out Hrugga’s take on table manners, gambling and more.

The Relative Status of the Legions
Jack Bramah assesses the pecking-order within the Tsolyáni military hierarchy.

The Profession of Arms
Got your heart set on becoming a soldier? Dave Morris considers what a big difference clan makes.

The Clan of the Iron Plume
Mark Wigoder-Daniels takes a walk around this scribe’s clan-house. Discover the intrigues and heart-aches that lie behind those ink pots and scrunched-up bits of papyrus.

Joyful Sitting Amongst Friends
Send us your letters; tell us your views.

Tusmikang Khawenlitusmi!
Any fool can batter someone to death with the business end of a chlen-hide sword. Patrick Brady demonstrates how to do it with style.

Best Savoured Cold
Blue light, chimes and the smell of cinnamon... Be afraid. Be very afraid.

The Excellent Travelling Volume
Dermot Bolton pens his first chapter from the land of Jannu.
Tékumel Products Review

Tsolyáni Names for Games

Recent History

109956.name: Dragontales
109956.description:
An anthology of all-new fantasy fiction

From the inside cover:
An original collection of fantasy fiction and art, presented by the publishers of Dragon magazine.

Featuring a new tale in the Niall of the Far Travels series by Gardner F. Fox, and nine other never-before-published stories.

109957.name: The Eye of All-Seeing Wonder (Issue 2 - Autumn 1993)
rpgissuearticle: The Lament to the Wheel of Black
The Land of the Manifest Spirit
109957.description:
table of contents:
Opening the Way
Editorial from Dave Morris.

Crystal Clear
Travel south to the Kerunan Protectorate, where Dermot Bolton unfolds a tale steeped in skulduggery and dark doings. A scenario for TIRIKELU.

The Lament to the Wheel of Black
The great epic of the creation of Tékumel and the Battle of Dormoron Plain, described by Mark Wigoder-Daniels.

The Land of the Manifest Spirit
Steve Foster takes the express tubeway car to a country beyond the western horizon. A long way beyond.

Joyful Sitting Amongst Friends
Put your weapons in the rack by the door, seat yourselves according to dais and get ready for some convivial chit-chat.

Wizards in White Hats
The strange occult secrets of Livyánu, land of sorcery, are revealed by Jamie Thomson.

Barbarous Experiment
Michael Cule explains why the heroes of last Issue’s scenario came from outside the Empire.

In the Wrong Hands
A systemless scenario in which curiosity might well kill the tiuni, by Dave Morris.

Count Your Blessings
Paul Mason explains how to make the most of the shadowy boundary between superstition and real magic.

109958.name: White Wolf Magazine (Issue 36 - Jun 1993)
109958.description:
"Six Years of Independent Roleplaying Coverage"

Cover by David O. Miller

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

109959.name: Jolly Circus
109959.description:
Race game which tries to be original in that you have two pieces (an animal and a rider) you can consider moving after you have thrown the die. After both pieces have started separately, the players must get their two pieces together on the same square. Once achieved, you can move both as one unit because you cannot win whilst your two pieces are apart.
First to the end of the track with rider mounted on animal, wins.

109960.name: Valkyrie (Issue 21 - 2000)
109960.description:
"The Independent Role Playing Game Magazine"

Cover Pic - Doomstones 3: The Heart of Chaos

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

109961.name: Travel Agent
109961.description:
Card game that owes a debt to Rummy as a similar game mechanic but with a lot of extra options.
The objective is to use all the cards in your hand first, by laying down cards that represent a journey. A journey may include such cards as destinations, Visas, passports and currencies.
When a player 'goes out', all the cards played by him onto a single journey or multiple journeys, will score him points. The black number on each card represents the card's value. Cards also have a red number, and that is the penalty value of cards not yet used by the opponents.
Six deals equals a game. The player with the most points after those six deals, wins.

109962.name: Breakout! (Issue 40 - Sep 1990)
rpgissuearticle: How to Consistently Lose at Wastelands
109962.description:
Cover "Legends" by Danny Willis

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

109963.name: Airport Flying Game
109963.description:
Contents: 4 plastic aeroplanes, one die and a board. The instructions are on the back of the box.
A simple roll and move game. Each player starts in a different corner of the board and will advance their pawn along one of four tracks (coloured Red, Green, Yellow or Blue. No two players must use the same track. Then you roll and move, obeying instructions if you land on special squares. First to London wins.

109964.name: Turas
109964.description: A game whose aim is to improve your mastery of the Gaelic language. The game focuses on increasing players' exposure to 12 frequently-used, improper Gaelic verbs. An audio cassette is included so that players can hear native speakers pronouncing Gaelic words and phrases. Players roll a D6, land on a numbered square of the colorful board, and refer to one of six laminated lists to find the corresponding instructions for that space. The instructions are written in Gaelic, and the current player must respond to the instructions correctly. The winner is the first player to get his token to the end of the board. Players are to speak entirely in Gaelic while playing.

109965.name: Mediterranean Cruise
109965.description:
Race game with some novel twists.
The track on the board takes you on a journey to England. 18 picture cards are shuffled and placed face down on numbered circles at the top of the board. On your journey, should you land on the same numbered square as one of the circles above, you take the face-down picture card. This card is a souvenir of your trip and will score the points indicated. Only the first player to arrive at a square that is linked to a circle above, can take the picture card.
The first player to reach England gains 10 points. Now everyone counts up the points on their souvenir cards and the player with the most points, wins.
One unusual rule. If you arrive home with the Slave-Girl (souvenir?!) cannot arrive in England with such a find. It must be returned to the board and he can choose any other souvenir card that is still unowned. England would appear to be the only country in Europe that bans slaves! By the way, if you want a Slave-Girl of your own, the place to go is Istanbul (square 65).

109966.name: Midget Golf For The Table
109966.description:
Super-sized tabletop golf game.
Play real golf shots with your miniature metal golf clubs. The greens are represented by green card with holes in the centre. The ball must go constantly onto the floor I would think (out of bounds?).
The box says:
An exact counterpart, in miniature, of the popular outdoor pastimeComplete with Golf Clubs, Balls, Putting Greens, Bunkers and full instructions. This game of skill entrances the Golf enthusiast as well as the learner.A really scientific Game of Golf can be played indoors with the appliances without any risk of injury to furniture.

I love that last line of the box text.

109967.name: Picture Rummy
109967.description:
Not Rummy at all, but it is a set collecting game.
The top left corner of a picture and the bottom right of the same picture are placed in such a way that you can add 9 cards between them to form a finished picture. You draw and play cards to your picture much the same as you would in most card games of this type.
The pictures are very nice (see image for a coaching scene for example).
The first player to complete a picture, wins.

boardgamecompilation: Sentinels of the Multiverse: 5th Anniversary Foil Hero Collection
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Complete Hero Variant Collection
109968.description:
Pauline Felicia Parsons, the daughter of Paul Parsons VIII, having just turned 18, developed new powers of her own.

Innate Power: "Atomic Glare" - Legacy deals 1 target 3 Energy damage.
109968.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Young Legacy Promo Card

109969.description:
Just outside Meeptropolis, several meeples on a camping trip are attacked by a swarm of giant radioactive butterflies. As a result, they all gain super speed and one other unique superpower, turning them into...Mutant Meeples!

The city of Meeptropolis has long been in decay, with crimes happening one after the other all over the city. The city council has asked YOU to put together the best possible team of Mutant Meeples to serve as protectors for their fine city.

Mutant Meeples is a puzzle game based on Alex Randolph's game Ricochet Robots in which players are looking to find the shortest "path" to get their meeples to the scene of the crime before any of the other players, using a clever combination of Mutant Meeples and their unique superpowers and super speed. If you're the fastest to the scene of the crime, you add a meeple to your super team; the first player to fill his super team with Mutant Meeples wins!

But there's a catch – once one of your meeples has reached the scene of the crime, he no longer participates. (After all, he’s already "made the team".) This gives players who have fewer meeples on their super teams more options, and provides an additional challenge to players whose super team is almost full.

Mutant Meeples contains a huge 22" double-sided board, eight custom super-powered Mutant Meeples, and much much more.

Also included is the expansion:

Mutant Meeples: Sidekicks allows for more variety in Mutant Meeples thanks to two new super-powered meeples – Nacho Fast and SwapMeet – that can be used in place of those in the original game, as well as tiles that modify both sides of the game board, making them easier or more difficult to match your cranial capacity.
109969.name: Mutant Meeples
boardgamepodcastepisode: ET88: Merchant & Seacabó, esto es tó
The Spiel at Essen 2011 - Bezier Games

109970.name: Home
109970.description:
Home is a game of skill where the players have as principal aim displace his cards and manage to reach the cabin "HOME".

Objective: To mark six points in the cabin HOME, placed in the center of the board.

Beginning: One distributes in a random way to every player 3 cards.

Placement you register: There are placed 3 cards received in the cabin corresponding to his number in the end of the board to the right of the cabin "Beginning"

The first player: One adds the values of every card that the player has received. The player with major quantity, is the player in moving first.

Movement: It is possible to displace in every shift a maximum of "1 card" to an adjacent cabin on the one that is.

Every cabin corresponds to one of six cards of game, thus on having placed on a cabin with number "1" it corresponds to which is the turn to move to the card "1" and here to depend that player is his owner.

The value of this system resides in whom he is the owner of the card who has to play in the new shift.

Marking points: Once there is reached the central cabin HOME, there is marked " 1 point ". Later, the card that has reached the cabin HOME, returns to his initial cabin in the zone of beginning of the board corresponding to the player.

Winner: The first player who marks 6 points, which it is equal when reaches the cabin HOME six times.

Special rules: Every player possesses his area of playground. It is not possible to invade the opposite field.

Once there is reached the Cabin HOME and the card is returned to his cabin of corresponding exit, there is activated the norm of the following card in moving, being this same to a new adjacent cabin.

109971.name: Das Schwarze Auge: Meisterschirm (DSA 3rd Edition)
109971.description:
User Summary:

A trifold screen with a 28 page booklet called Tabellen (tables).

The screen is a collage of various covers Ugurcan Yüce painted for The Dark Eye over the years.

109973.name: The Eye of All-Seeing Wonder (Issue 3 - Spring 1994)
rpgissuearticle: The Clan of the Red Flower
109973.description:
Table of contents:

Opening the Way
Editorial from Dave Morris.

The City of Pála Jakálla
Jack Bramah shows us round the streets and clanhouses of this colourful southern town.

Joyful Sitting Amongst Friends
The Plaque of Joyous Conviviality hangs by the door; Chumetl and sweetmeats are to hand. Come and join the party.

Servants of the Petal Throne
Mark Wigoder-Daniels reveals the secret inner workings of the Palace of the Realm. It wouldn’t have happened under the old Emperor.

Thusúli Tlamúsun!
Ever wondered what the Tsolyáni have for dinner? Here’s what they’re serving at the Sea Blue clanhouse tonight.

INTERNECINE!
Washed up on a desert island with a beautiful foreign princess. What more could a young marine wish for? A Lightning Bringer, for one thing...

Blue Murder
Violence may be the last resort of the ignorant, but there’s no reason to let it bankrupt you as well. Take a look at our guide to staying solvent after the dust has settled.

Keeping the Peace
An entire campaign based in Pala Jakálla, for players who don’t mind not being wealthy young layabouts for a change.

The Clan of the Red Flower
As a tie-in to the feature on Pala Jakálla, we take a closer look at this seafaring clan.

109974.description:

109978.description:
User Summary:

The first of three books from the german fan zine Der Letzte Held about the harbor city of Havena.

it contains descriptions of nine buildings, an adventure, an article about faith and religion in Havena and a listing of persons found in this book and book 2 (Licht und Schatten).

109979.name: Tarnkappe
109979.description:
Every player gets six differnt colored marbles and 6 same-color caps. One cap is pulled over each marble. The marbles must reach the goal in the right order. The players rolls a die to move the caps over the board. If the player rolls a 6 he can look under on of his caps. The first player who finished the sequence wins the game.

the goal sequences can be changed.

109980.name: Licht und Schatten
109980.description:
User Summary:

109981.name: Fuchsfährten
109981.description:
User Summary:

The third of three books from the german fan zine Der Letzte Held about the harbor city of Havena.

109982.name: Havena: Heute & Gestern
109982.description:
User Summary:

A map of the city of Havena including the sunken parts of the city.
It comes with an 18 page booklet Gestern & Heute containing an article about PCs in Havena and an adventure.

109983.name: Der Dunkle Tod
109983.description:
User Summary:

An Adventure in the city of Havena about a poisoning before a swimming contest to be held at a great fair in the city.

109984.name: Scales and Salvage
109984.description:
from the introduction

While exploring the ruins of an Ancient temple of learning, the players discover a dug-out entrance that leads to the basement level beneath a collapsed building.

An alliance of sleeths and menarls have been working together to loot the university's ruins, and have stumbled upon a remarkable find -- a humanoid android, albeit one trapped within the confines of an electrical cage.

This Gamma Delve is designed for 4 characters of level 1, but can be scaled for anywhere between 2 and 6 characters.

109985.name: Drôl: Die Farbkarte der Kaufmannsstadt
109985.description:
User Summary:

A coloured map of the city of Drôl and some of the surrounding villages.

109986.name: The Ray-Gun Revolution
109986.description:
from the introduction

The town of Two Suns is in trouble! The Mayor of Two Suns needs help protecting the town from a dangerous Warlord named Ronnie. The heroes must investigate the Boneyard, a bizarre and dangerous graveyard for Ancient flying machines south of Two Suns, and Ronnie’s home base.

This adventure is designed for a group of four player characters with an average level of 4, and uses maps and monsters from Famine in Far-Go. The encounters give details on how to scale the adventure for more or fewer players.

First run at Amazing Discoveries in Tucson, Arizona, January 8, 2011.

109995.name: Love It! Hate It!
109995.description:
Love It! Hate It! is a game that asks how well you really know your friends and family. Do you know what type of super power they would love and hate to have? Could you name with whom they would love and hate to be trapped in an elevator?

Each round, someone reads a scenario card out loud and waits for their friends to secretly reveal what they think the card reader would love and hate in the situation. Once all the answers have been written on the dry-erase speech bubbles, one person holds the speech bubbles over the card reader's head and reads the answers out loud. The card reader will then pick the answer they liked best from the Love It options and the Hate It options. If your answer is picked, you get a chip. The object is to get three Love It chips and three Hate It chips to win.

The game comes with 18 Love It chips, 18 Hate It chips, 294 scenarios on 147 cards, three two-sided blank cards, six dry-erase speech bubbles, six dry-erase markers, a chip bag, a bubble tray, and rules.

109998.description: There are 8 cards for each of the 8 themes. In play 8 rows with the themes are laid out, each theme once in every row, the first player to place all his cards wins the game. In his move a player lays down as many cards as he wants, never two cards from one theme into the same row, but always in the same sequence of themes. If a player cannot place cards, he can switch cards with his stack. Before each placement round players fill up their hands to the maximum and then draw a card from their neigbour.
109998.name: Erstes Wissen Indianer

109999.description: There are 60 cards in the game with a knight motive and 15 theme cards, which show four motives belonging to the theme. Players must attribute the motive cards to the theme cards. The player placing the last motive card next to a theme card, receives all 5 cards, the first player to collect 4 theme groups wins the game. In his move a player draws 2 cards and discards two cards, either placing them next to theme cards or onto the discard pile.
109999.name: Erstes Wissen Ritter

110000.description: The game has 60 dinosaur cards showing 60 different dinosaurs. The header of the card states four facts: size, length and weight of the dinosaur and how many million years ago it lived. Players start with 6 cards, the die determines a category for each round, players then play one card. The player who has played the highest value in the current category wins all cards of the round. When all cards are played, the player with the most cards wins the game.
110000.name: Erstes Wissen Saurier
